content.description:
Climb brown patina to a bolt ~20' off the ground.  While the climbing is easy, it is not trivial and a fall here would not be good.  Continue up past a few more bolts, then place a few pieces of gear (#1 Camalot and a couple of smaller pieces) before continuing up to a final mantle before the anchor.  Overall, good climbing on edges and a few smears.

This route feels similar in grade and maybe a bit more sustained and heady than 'Pine Creek Moss-acre' just to the right.
content.protection:
9 bolts, a few pieces to 1"

70m rope
content.location: The farthest left route on the main slab at St. Valentine's Slab, just to the right of a gully and triangular slab (see topo pic route B).

content.description: Climb a crack/seam to face and final sloping move before the anchor.  Fun slab climbing on mostly edges.
content.protection: 9 bolts, 70m rope, anchor shared with 'Pommie On A Slabscape'
content.location: The start follows the obvious crack/seam on the left side of the main St. Valentine's Slab (just to the right of 'Pommie On A Slabscape')

content.description:
Starting over the left side of the overhang at the base (just right of the diagonal crack/seam) follow a line of bolts over small edges and a few smears to underneath the left leaning arch/roof.  From the bolt below the fragile arch/roof it is possible to go up right and follow the arch toward the left or make a couple of small face moves up and left to easier ground (recommended).  Climb over the small lip (caution!) then head up and right to the anchor shared with 'Hallmark Holiday'.

Notes:

- our 70m rope was a couple of feet short of the ground.  Not a big deal, but pay attention!

- my partner dislodged a foothold (while going over the lip/roof/arch) that turned out to be a 12x8x2" little slab that exploded 10' from me.  This stuff happens, but wear a helmet and pay attention!  A chunk of rock like that can ruin your day ;-)
content.location: The bolted route immediately to the right of 'Pine Creek Moss-acre' (the right leaning diagonal crack/seam).

content.description:
This route goes up and over the right side of the overhang at the base.  Follow small edges up to easier ground, then move past another (easier than below) thin section to the anchor.  The crux moves on this route felt harder and more sustained than 'Bloody Mary.'

Note:

- our 70m rope was a couple of feet short of the ground.  Not a big deal, but pay attention!
content.location: Right side of the low overhang at the base.
